properties.media:imagetext:
CATHAY HOTEL
SHANGHAI APRIL 29, 1933
I have been very busy negotiating with the various Chinese officials who
are directly or indirectly interested in Commercial aviation. T he Post Office is under
the Commissioner of Posts who in turn is under the Minister of Communications, each of te
several officials with whom I hav e to deal has a number of advisors, secretarys ete ete
Time is of absolutely no concern
to any of them and the surest way in the world not to
get what you want is to try to rush them.
The moment they think you are trying to hurry
things along that is the sign to cease firing
and drop back. They go on the theory that
a year or two more or less is of no consequence at all. That anyone who tries to push
ahead has something to cover up and therefore is interested in making away with the sale
his gold brick before the tarnish begins to show.
Therefore I have had to appear at
all times as though time was no consideration. It is fatal also for any foreigner to say
anything about going home or reserving space for a certain date unless he has everything
completely buttoned-up. The moment they think you are about to leave they start bringing
out new objections,
and knowing that you cannot afford to go home with nothing done,
depend on forcing all sorts of concessions. The foregoing sounds as though I did not like
the Chinese, which as a matter of fact is far from the truth. I am really strong for them.
They are terribly hard traders, have a system all their own and hav e learned in the bitter
school of experience that the foreigners who visit China on commercial business are mostly
here to exploit the people for whom they profess such ardent friendship. Many foreigners
who have bribed or cheated themselves into a situation complain about the treatment they
have received.
When the facts are known you will usually find that the Chinese have done
about what anyone else would have done under similar circumstances. I have no patience
either with the great majority of foreigners who having liv ed in China for many many years
still find all sort of fault with the Chinese, call them a lot of crooks thieves and robber
and generally run down the country and everyone in it. I dont think any of us are over
our health and if we make a living out of our residence in China we ought to either
get along without beng so critical or go home.
and I have taken a room or rather suite of rooms on the fifth floor
of this hotel overlooking the Bund, the cost in my case at least being less than I was pay-
ing before. Our suite is what the publicity man for the hotel calls the Indian Suite. It
room is about twenty feet square and off that is an office about the same size. There are
two large closets and also two trunk rooms large enough to hold ten trunks each. The whole
My companion on this trip Groeger sailed for home last Sunday. He was the happiest
Dutchman in the world. He had been to the Philippines and all around, finished his survey
and done a grand job of it all. The dirt and lack of order in China had I fear got on his
teutonic nerves. Then too he was deathly afraid of all the small places and feared constant-
ly that he was going to be taken by bandits or pirates. Of course most of the stories you
read at home are wrong - it is about as fair to judge China by the stories which get into
the newspapers as to judge America by the Hearst head lines or the impression that many
have that Chicago is a place where you will be very lucky to escape being mowed down by
mac hine gun fire.
There are lots of rumors around that the Yangstz e River for instance is
lined on either bank by bandits who shoot passengers just for fun, The fact is that in three
years of regular operation of China National Aviation Corporation for over a thousand miles
up the river our pilinta pilots have flown entirely unmolested except that one pilot was
shot in the leg by a stray bullet or the plane was actuallyfired upon by someone who prob-
ably thought it was a Japanese bomber for the particular incident happened during the
Japanese trouble a year ago. I asked Groeger to get in touch with Debby and show her all the
plunder which he took home for Pawley and incidentally give her the few things which I hav e
dared to purchase and last but not least tell her about our trip and my present state of
health and behavior - both of which thank you are excellent.
Thursday night I went to a Movie Queen ball. It was one of those charity affairs
staged in all American towns and usually sponsored by the Elks or some Rotarian type of
bores.
Here however it was quite new and the sponsors were Sir Victor Sassoon and Mrs. Dr.
Fearn. The latter is a sister of Mrs. Oscar Johnson of St. Louis and remembered Father and
Mother very well from their trip of 1919. I went to the ball
as her guest. The Chinese
beauties were really good looking in their Chinese dresses. The prize however was won by a
Russian and she will get a free trip to Hollywood, which however probably does not suspect
taht she is on her way. She was very good looking but will probably not get very far in the
This is Saturday night and I am glad to have an evening to myself but I do have
some work to do so will sign off. I do not even dare suggest to you when I may be able to
Leave here for Hong Kong and Manila, but it will almost certainly not be for several weeks.
My very best to you all
